quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Work and Energy
quiz.subtitle: Unit 3 Quiz 1 – Application of Work-Energy Theorem
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Work-Energy Theorem, Kinetic Energy, Conservation of Energy

questions.question: A 4 kg object is pushed from rest by a constant net force of 12 N along a frictionless horizontal surface. After moving 6 m, what is its kinetic energy?
questions.explanation: By Work-Energy Theorem: W_net = ΔKE. W = F × d = 12 × 6 = 72 J. Since initial KE = 0, final KE = 72 J.

questions.question: A block of mass 2 kg slides down a smooth inclined plane of height 5 m from rest. What is its speed at the bottom? (Use g = 10 m/s²)
A 10 kg box moving at 3 m/s on a rough floor comes to rest after sliding 4.5 m. What is the magnitude of the average friction force?
questions.explanation: KE_initial = ½ × 10 × 3² = 45 J, KE_final = 0. Work by friction = −F_f × d = −45 ⇒ F_f × 4.5 = 45 ⇒ F_f = 10 N.

questions.question: A spring with k = 200 N/m is compressed by 0.1 m and launches a 0.5 kg block horizontally on a frictionless table. What is the block’s speed?
questions.explanation: Elastic PE = ½ k x² = ½ × 200 × 0.01 = 1 J. Converts to KE: 1 = ½ × 0.5 × v² ⇒ v² = 4 ⇒ v = 2 m/s.

questions.question: A car of mass 1000 kg increases speed from 10 m/s to 20 m/s. What is the net work done on the car?
A crane lifts a 200 kg load at constant speed vertically upward through 15 m. What is the net work done on the load?
questions.explanation: Constant speed ⇒ ΔKE = 0 ⇒ by Work-Energy Theorem, W_net = 0 (net force = 0, so net work = 0).

questions.question: A bullet of mass 0.02 kg traveling at 200 m/s penetrates a wooden block and emerges at 100 m/s. If the block is 0.1 m thick, what is the average resistive force from the wood?
A force of 20 N acts on a 5 kg object initially at rest over a distance of 10 m on a frictionless surface. What is the object’s final kinetic energy?
questions.explanation: Work = F × d = 20 × 10 = 200 J. By Work-Energy Theorem: KE_f − 0 = 200 J.

questions.question: A roller coaster car of mass 500 kg starts from rest at point A at height 50 m above ground, reaches point B at height 10 m above ground. Ignoring friction, what is its speed at B? (g = 10 m/s²)
A skater on horizontal ice glides to a stop due to friction. If initial speed is 6 m/s and coefficient of kinetic friction is 0.1, how far does she travel before stopping? (g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Initial KE = ½ m (36) = 18m J. Work by friction = −μ_k m g d = −0.1 × m × 10 × d = −m × d. By Work-Energy: −m d = −18m ⇒ d = 18 m.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent understanding of Work-Energy Theorem applications.
scoreMessages.70: Good grasp; practice energy conservation in systems with friction.
scoreMessages.50: Fair; review the theorem W_net = ΔKE and solving for speed or force.
scoreMessages.0: Needs review of work-energy concepts and kinetic energy calculations.
